article_title: Last Man Standing episode guide and recap for episode 8, season 4
article_text:

Listing: LA Modern Family Mom The Mother/Daughter Experiment: Celebrity Edition Mr. Robot Mulaney The Musketeers The Mysteries of Laura Nathan for You NCIS: New Orleans New Girl The Night Shift Nurse Jackie The O.C. The Odd Couple One Big Happy The Originals Parenthood Parks and Recreation Partners Person of Interest The Player Playing House Powers The Prancing Elites Project Pushing Daisies Quantico The Quest Ray Donovan Recovery Road Rectify The Red Road Restaurant Redemption Resurrection Rewrapped Rising Star Rookie Blue Roswell Rush Salem Satisfaction Scorpion Scream Seed Selfie Sex and the City Shadowhunters Shameless Shark Tank The Slap Sleepy Hollow Soap Operas South Park Star Wars Rebels Static Shock The Strain Submissions Only Supernatural Switched at Birth Tales from the Crypt Teachers Total Divas Town of the Living Dead True TV Confessions Two and a Half Men Tyrant Unbreakable Kimmy Schmidt Undateable Under the Dome Vanderpump Rules Veronica Mars Vicious The Voice The Walking Dead Welcome to Sweden The West Wing White Collar The Wil Wheaton Project Witches of East End The X-Files You're the Worst Young and Hungry Younger 'Last Man Standing' tackles Obamacare Season 4 | Episode 8 | “Risky Behavior” | Aired Nov 14, 2014 Related 'Last Man Standing' Somebody's got the pox 'Last Man Standing' Death and taxes 'Last Man Standing' Halloween election If you have spent any time watching this show, you know that Mike Baxter is as politically conservative as they come. Whether you agree or disagree with his politics, you’ve got to admit that political satire is always enjoyable when it’s written well. Such is the case with Last Man Standing. Whether Mike is arguing with Ryan over immigration or Chuck Larabee about racial stereotypes, the writers on this show always demonstrate both sides of the issue. Tonight’s episode of Last Man Standing is no different. When an Outdoor Man employee crashes his motorcycle, Ed Alzate decides to implement some strict health codes at work. He wants to fight the rising cost of health care, but at what cost to his employees? Mike, who is ostentatiously against the Affordable Care Act, stands up for the staff, forcing Ed to consider how much control he really has over them. Let’s just blame Obamacare At Outdoor Man, Kyle is recovering from his motorcycle accident. He has a concussion and a large bandage on his head. He got so banged up because he wasn’t wearing a helmet. Apparently Colorado does not have any laws that require riders to wear helmets. As Mike says, you can drive your motorcycle to the pot store without a helmet, and then go buy a gun. Oh Colorado, don’t you cry for me. This spurs Mr. Alzate on a rant about health care. He claims that accidents like Kyle’s can raise Outdoor Man’s health care costs, which Ed is already having trouble keeping up with, now that Obamacare has gone into effect. Mike, always ready with a zinger about Obama, says, “But I thought you could keep your current plan under Obamacare.” I think we all know how Mike feels about President Obama at this point. Unfortunately, the rising costs of health care, compounded by Kyle’s accident, makes Ed want to cancel the employee health care plan all together. Mike, who loves his employees, disagrees with Mr. Alzate, so Ed is forced to come up with a new plan to lower costs. Back at the Baxters’, Mike and his family discuss the possibility of Outdoor Man canceling their employee health care plan. Mandy and Vanessa think it’s great that the government wants to take care of people, but Mike says it’s not the government who paid for Kyle’s hospital bills—it was Outdoor Man. But Mike thinks employers should choose to offer health care benefits, instead of being forced to do so by the government—like a spouse volunteering to wash the dishes, instead of being nagged to do them. Kyle brings his motorcycle over to the Baxters’ to get fixed, which greatly upsets Mandy. Kyle promises to wear a helmet from now on, but Mandy doesn’t want him to ride the motorcycle at all. Kyle agrees to sell the bike so Mandy doesn’t have to worry about his safety. Unfortunately, he is talked out of selling the bike by Mike, who thinks Kyle should have the freedom to take risks. Kyle isn’t the best decision maker, and being stuck between his girlfriend and his boss puts him in a tough spot. After a losing streak, Eve’s team finally catches a break when Eve throws the winning touchdown. Mike can’t help himself, bragging to everyone that his daughter won the game. The elation is not to last, as Eve comes home depressed after her coach benches her. Apparently the field-goal fake-out was her idea, not his. Bad, bad sugar Back at Outdoor Man, Kyle is throwing away chips, doughnuts, cream, and sugar because Mr. Alzate is trying to get all of his employees healthy. I think Ed is trying to go the preventive health care route on this one, but will everyone be on board? Mike looks for Ed and instead finds Ed’s girlfriend, Wendy, doing yoga with the employees. Can you imagine? A dozen burly guys doing yoga. Mike is not impressed. The employees claim that they are enjoying the yoga, but Ed is worried it isn’t enough. He wants to stop them from doing anything that requires risk: biking, jet-skiing, rock climbing. Except Outdoor Man sells all the equipment required for these risky endeavors. Obviously, Ed is getting a little too carried away. At what point does an employer cross the line when he starts controlling what his employees can and cannot do? Ed is very close to that line. In Mike’s opinion, Ed has already crossed it. No more namaste for Outdoor Man. Back at home, Eve’s coach continues to punish her for her fake play. Even though Eve loves kicking for the team, she considers quitting. Mike encourages Eve that it’s important for her to follow her coach’s plays, even if she doesn’t agree with them, because the team is depending on her. In the military, Eve couldn’t call an audible because lives are at stake. Mike believes that Eve should do the same thing on the football field—trust her coach as if he were her commanding officer. Eve decides to stay on the team. Ed finally stops his health care brigade when he realizes he cannot control the lives of his employees. He brings back the doughnuts and gets rid of the yoga class. He can encourage his employees to be healthy and safe, like having Kyle wear his helmet, but he can’t control their choices in life. Lastly, Ed drops a bomb on everyone when he announces that he and Wendy are pregnant! Say what?! Mr. Alzate is going to be a dad! In his Outdoor Man vlog, Mike says doing anything to the extreme is bad for your health. Whether it’s overeating or undereating, overexercising or underexercising, everything should be done in moderation (including making political statements about Obamacare). Last Man Standing airs Fridays 8/9C on ABC. Please enable JavaScript to view the comments powered by Disqus.
